ygData.subject: Obsessive Optimization
ygData.msgSnippet: ... I ve got good reason to be obsessive.  Let me give you an example: Before I can evaluate my networks, I ve got to calculate the expected results.  I do

>From: Ian Badcoe <ian_badcoe@...>

>But this is getting into the realms of the obsessive :)

I've got good reason to be obsessive.  Let me give you an example:

Before I can evaluate my networks, I've got to calculate the expected 
results.  I do that once and only once, and then refer back to those 
calculations for each network.  That saves me from doing it 999 times more 
than I need to, which is good.

My inputs are converted from pixel values to a 'relative intensity' in the 
range of +/- 1.  So, naturally, I want the expected output to be in that 
same range.  So, after I shrink the 144x144 to 9x9, I convert the 9x9 into 
the +/-1 range, and use those same parameters to shrink the original inputs. 
  Then, I have to calculate the expected results, which requires taking the 
average of every possible square area within the 144x144 region.  There are 
1,005,720 such regions.  Calculating those expected results was taking 
around 10 minutes...  I could have just settled for that.  But I didn't...

I decided to keep things as integers until the last possible step.  Leave 
the pixels as 16 bit unsigned integers.  To take the average, add them up 
and store the result in a 32 bit long.  Convert to a double when dividing by 
the number of pixels that make up the area.  Then convert that average to 
the +/-1 range.  WOW!  It did the same amount of work in about 10 seconds!  
Talk about orders of magnitude!

The next thing to attack is the time it takes to generate the evaluation 
code.  Generating code that evaluates 500 networks on a single sample takes 
on average of about one minute for my laptop.  It takes less than 5 minutes 
to compile and execute that code.  So a savings there is significant, and 
there is definitely inefficiencies in the process.  So next on my agenda is 
to speed up that process.  I'm contemplating writing code which outputs code 
that is specific to a topology, and then calling that generated code with a 
specific network in order to output the optimized activation function.  
That'll be a debugging nightmare! But cool, in a morbid way...

But I'm glad I'm obsessive, I have saved myself boatloads of time in this 
experiment!
